name: Factoring Devastating Criticals into average damage
author: darktooth

posts.author: darktooth
posts.content:
It started with me imagining a fight between two lvl40 melee characters, A and B:
 
A: Strength 41
     AC 54
     HP 640
     AB 59 (5 APR when hasted)
     Damage: 1-8 + 20 (Critical: 15-20/ x2)
     +2d6 elemental damage
     +10 physical damage
     Fortitude: 40
 
B: Strength 52
     AC 76
     HP 460
     AB 63 (5 APR when hasted)
     Damage: 1-6 + 30 (Critical: 12-20/ x2)
     +2d6 elemental damage
     +10 physical damage
     Fortitude: 42
 
Obviously, B would win if they are pitted against each other. But curiosity drove me to determine how much damage B can inflict against A, and vice versa. I don’t have the tools, such as Kamiryn’s CBC or Yunim’s ADPPRCalc, so I only used a basic calculator to compute. I included Dev crit chance in my computations.
 
A against B:
APR of +59/+54/+49/+44/+59 against 76 AC will land 11 hits in 20 rounds, all criticals, will have 10% Dev crit chance against 42 Fortitude
 
My formula:
1-8 +20 = 24.5 (average damage on normal hit)
Overwhelming critical: 24.5 x 2 + 3.5 (average of 1d6) + 7 (average elemental damage) + 10 physical damage = 69.5 damage
10% Dev crit chance means 1.1 out of 11 hits dealing 460 damage (B's HP) each
Total damage in 20 rounds: (1.1 x 460) + (9.9 x 69.5) = 1194.05 damage
 
B against A:
APR of +63/+58/+53/+48/+63 against 54 AC will land 91 hits in 20 rounds, 45 of them criticals, will have 50% Dev crit chance against 40 Fortitude
Normal hits: 50.5 x 46 (number out of 91) = 2,323 damage
Overwhelming critical: 87.5 x 22.5 (half of 45 criticals) = 1968.75 damage
Dev crit: 640 (A's HP) x 22.5 (other half of 45 criticals) = 14,400 damage
Total damage in 20 rounds : 2,323 + 1968.75 + 14,400 = 18,691.75 damage
 
One can derive the ADPR by dividing the total damage by 20.

Am I missing something here? Anyone who has better understanding of the mechanics please feel free to correct me if I’m wrong.

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Hey Darktooth!

This is an interesting thought. I understand your curiosity, but what would be the point of calculating the damage potential of DevCrit other that curiosity itself? The thing is that when DevCrit hits, it's over, combat ends instantly, so it's more like the opposite of damage, which until you reach 0 HP, means combat continues, and you can react. How do you quantify the fact that enemies can't heal against a DevCrit? How do you account for the damage the character who is DevCritted has already suffered before getting DevCritted? Because more likely than not, the enemy won't be at full HP when they do go down.

Also, if you consider that formula, then DevCrit would do more damage against foes with higher HP, linking the damage not to the DevCrit itself, but to enemy HP. A similar way of thinking would apply if you tried to convert insta-death spells into Fireballs using that logic.

I like the idea, but I don't see the practical application of it, yet.

Cheers!

darktooth wrote: ↑

But now, probably another nonsense, question popped in my mind--how does one compute for average damage that excludes Dev crit? In the above example, B could dev crit A 22.5% of the time, that's hard to overlook. I must be very sleepy already.
Assume average damage rolls on all damage dice, then add the modifiers, and multiply by % chance to hit (removing crit chance), then add the result of that to the % of times you actually crit x the damage multiplied by the weapon multiplier), That would be my guess.

The thing that is a little obscure to me is the chance of critting, because it involves a threat roll.

I guess it would be something like this:

average damage on a regular hit = (average damage on dice rolls + modifiers) x (average chance to hit - chance to crit).

average damage on criticals = ((average damage on rolls + modifiers) x weapon multiplier) x average chance to crit

total average damage = average damage on a regular hit + average damage on criticals (since the chances have been factored in in previous calculations)

I may be wrong, but that's what makes sense to me.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
In this case you're not really interested in the average damage, you're interested in which build will (on average) kill the other build first.
It's possible to calculate the average damage per round and the average number of successful critical hits per round, but combining them is a bit complicated.
It would only be possible to calculate the average number of rounds before the builds killed each other using that information, so a proper comparison might not be completely possible.
You could also do it on an attack-by-attack basis instead of a round-by-round basis, but that would be even more complicated.
I'll see if I can edit my ADPRCalc to help with the comparison.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
I calculated the Average Damage Per Round (ADPR), Average Devastating Critical Hits Per Round (ADCHPR), and combined them to calculate the Average Rounds To Death (ARTD).
Since the averages are calculated over a round any decimal places in the ARTD aren't really reliable for a comparison.

A vs A: ADPR - 238, ADCHPR - 0.261, ARTD - 2.3
A vs B: ADPR - 27, ADCHPR - 0.008, ARTD - 16.8
B vs A: ADPR - 353, ADCHPR - 1.0688, ARTD - 1.0
B vs B: ADPR - 73, ADCHPR - 0.137, ARTD - 4.7

So on average A takes around 17 rounds to kill B while B kills A in 1 round.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Keep in mind for this whole thing about calculating Dev Crit chances, that the RNG (Random Number Generator) of the game's engine that is responsible for producing the numbers for your rolls is digital & short of biased on delivering "clear/defining results". What do I mean by that? Simply that there is more chance of either very low or very high numbers than if you were rolling the dice yourself. And most of you can confirm with their senses that with either Baldur's Gate II or Neverwinter Nights, there are far more critical hits (or spectacular failures) than what the average numbers might say.

I remember an article about Pools of Radiance back in the day, they were saying (amongst others) that the RNG of the game was a failure since it was producing average numbers most of the time & low-level heroes (& monsters) couldn't hit the broad side of a barn.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
They're only equivalent in this case because the builds are being compared by fighting each other.
If we compared both builds against one specific target (with or without AS) then the attacker with EWF and no AS would have a higher ADPR than the attacker with AS and no EWF, unless the target's AC was either so high or so low that the +2 AB didn't matter at all.
If you compare an attacker without EWF against a defender without AS and then compare the same attacker/defender pair after giving them EWF and AS there won't be any difference in terms of ADPR.
However the extra AB will matter for non-ADPR related things, such as increasing the chance of a KD attempt succeeding.

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
I don't know if I'm going completely on a tangent here, but basically speaking, +1 AB allows you to hit once more every 20 attacks. 

So, by that logic, you can say that it largely depends on how much damage you do per hit, being less effective for DEX toons than for STR toons, because the former would do little damage per hit, whereas the latter, with an extra hit, would do significantly more damage.

EWS adds a fixed 4 to every hit you already make, so if you multiply the number of hits you have out of 20 (I.E. you hit 5x, on a 16, 17, 18, 19, and 20, some or all of which might end up being critical hits, doubling or tripling the damage). So you multiply it by 4 on normal hits, and by 8 or 12 on crits, multiplied by their specific chances to occur (the total of which needs to add up to 100%), and you'll have that average added damage, depending on several factors, such as: enemy AC, Weapon Multiplier, Weapon Crit Range, whether it's Keen or not, etc..

Then if that number you get is lower than the normal damage you do with a single regular attack, EP is better. If the number is higher, then EWS is better. Clearly, for DEX characters, EWS will likely be better than for STR ones.

That's my reasoning, but I really don't want to do the calculations.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
darktooth wrote: ↑

Just curious, how many rolls would you expect to see a streak of 5 numbers? Imagine a hasted PC rolling all 20s in a single attack round, is this possible?
It's 20^n, with n one less than the length of the streak if you're just looking for any number*, and as long as the streak if you're looking for a specific number. So a 5-streak of any number happens on average every 160,000 rolls and 5 20's in a row occur on average every 3,200,000 rolls.
I realise this slightly contradicts Yunim, but I think this is correct (Yunim, feel free to point out if I'm the one being incorrect).

* Think of how often "any number" appears: it's 20^0 = every roll

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Mirnaia is right, I wasn't accounting for each of the 20 possible streaks.
Probability of a streak of 1 out of 1 roll is 20 * (1/20) = 1 (obviously, this was a stupid mistake on my part)
Probability of a streak of 2 out of 2 rolls is 20 * (1/20)^2 = 1/20
Probability of a streak of 3 out of 3 rolls is 20 * (1/20)^3 = (1/20)^2 = 1/400
Probability of a streak of 4 out of 4 rolls is 20 * (1/20)^4 = (1/20)^3 = 1/8000
Probability of a streak of 5 out of 5 rolls is 20 * (1/20)^5 = (1/20)^4 = 1/160000
So if you rolled in sets of 1/2/3/4/5 you'd expect to encounter your first streak of length 1/2/3/4/5 after 1/20/400/8,000/160,000 sets of rolls.
However since there's overlap in the sets of rolls (rolling 6 times in a row is 1 set of 6 rolls, 2 sets of 5 rolls, 3 sets of 4 rolls, etc), you'd expect to encounter your first streak of length 5 after roughly 160,000 rolls rather than 160,000 sets of 5 rolls.

I compared the actual streaks from the two combat logs with randomly generated lists of rolls of equal length.
The "Actual Results" come from the combat logs, the "Test Results" are an average of streaks from 1,000 lists of randomly generated rolls.
The position in the list refers to the length of the streak, so the first entry is the number of streaks of length 1, etc.

Actual Log 1 Results (47358 rolls):
[42668, 2172, 107, 5, 1]
Test Results 1 (1000 sets of 47358 rolls):
[42744.646, 2134.614, 107.095, 5.363, 0.261, 0.014]
Actual Log 2 Results (29860 rolls):
[27000, 1303, 78, 5]
Test Results 2 (1000 sets of 29860 rolls):
[26951.683, 1345.623, 67.664, 3.308, 0.155, 0.012]

Since the actual results match up fairly well with the average test results it seems that the RNG is actually random, at least for attack rolls.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Not quite, the probability of rolling 10 20s out of 10 rolls is (1/20)^10 = 1 / (1.024 x 10^13). The probability of getting a streak of 10 for any number (1 - 20) out of 10 rolls is 20 * (1/20)^10 = (1/20)^9 = 1 / (5.12*10^11).
So you'd expect a 10 APR Monk to encounter their first roll of 10 20s in one round after around 1.024 x 10^13 rounds. That would take 6.144 x 10^13 seconds, or 1,946,957.7 years according to google. So it probably won't happen anytime soon.
